problem.tex: Using contour integration (that is, the residue theorem), evaluate \[\int_0^\infty\frac{dx}{1+x^2}.\]

solution.tex: First we note that $\frac{1}{1+x^2}$ is an $L^1$ even function, so $\int_0^\infty\frac{1}{1+x^2}dx=\frac{1}{2}\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{1+x^2}dx$. Tabling this for now, suppose $R>1$ and let $\gamma_R$ be the rainbow contour in $\mathbb{C}$ given by the straight line $L_R$ from $-R$ to $R$ and the arc $C_R$ from $R$ to $-R$ along the upper half of the circle $|z|=R$, oriented so that $\gamma_R$ has positive orientation. Then \[\lim_{R\to\infty}\int_{\gamma_R}\frac{1}{1+z^2}dz=\lim_{R\to\infty}\int_{L_R}\frac{1}{1+z^2}dz+\lim_{R\to\infty}\int_{C_R}\frac{1}{1+z^2}dz.\] We already know that $\lim_{R\to\infty}\int_{L_R}\frac{1}{1+z^2}dz=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{1+x^2}dx$, we shall show the $C_R$ component vanishes in the limit. \[\left|\int_{C_R}\frac{1}{1+z^2}dz\right|\leq\int_{C_R}\left|\frac{1}{1+z^2}\right||dz|\leq\int_{C_R}\frac{|dz|}{|z^2|-1}=\int_0^\pi\frac{Rdt}{R^2-1}=\frac{\pi R}{R^2-1}\to0.\] Therefore $\int_0^\infty\frac{1}{1+x^2}dx=\frac{1}{2}\lim_{R\to\infty}\int_{\gamma_R}\frac{1}{1+z^2}dz$. Moreover, Cauchy's integral theorem tells us that $\int_{\gamma_R}\frac{1}{1+z^2}dz$ does not depend on $R$ as long as $R>1$, because the only singularities of $\frac{1}{1+z^2}$ occur at $z=\pm i$. Thus $\int_0^\infty\frac{1}{1+x^2}dx=\frac{1}{2}\int_{\gamma_R}\frac{1}{1+z^2}dz$ for any $R>1$. Now $\frac{1}{1+z^2}=\frac{1}{2i}\left(\frac{1}{z-i}-\frac{1}{z+i}\right)$, and the residue theorem tells us that the integral of this function around $\gamma_R$ is $2\pi i\left(\frac{1}{2i}\right)=\pi$ because the only contributing residue is the $\frac{1}{2i}$ coming from the pole at $z=i$. Therefore $\int_0^\infty\frac{1}{1+x^2}dx=\frac{\pi}{2}$.
